p: Even in the absence of links to specific phenotypes or fitness, the identification of evolutionary responses at specific genes should help inform future on-ground studies focused on identifying the proximate causes of warming-related population declines across the range of this or other affected species [ 32]. Indeed, the potential for adaptive evolution to rescue populations in decline has emerged as an important concept in conservation biology [ 65], with increasing efforts to directly incorporate evolutionary principles into conservation planning [ 66]. As a cautionary note, our results suggest that putatively adaptive responses in T. alpinus at Alox15 ( Fig 4), as well as rapid shifts in functional morphology and diet [ 27, 30], have nonetheless been insufficient to prevent extensive extirpation of lower elevation populations of this alpine specialist.
